author: chrissorem

I’ve watched him mix numerous times and left thinking I could never make anything sound good in that room or with that approach but he’s managed to figure it out. author: Colin Althaus
content:
Now if you put this HPF on only the Side channel, at 100Hz what was originally +S becomes -S (180 degrees out of phase). So any 100Hz on the left now shifts to the right, and vice versa.

So say you have a rack tom with a fundamental at 100Hz panned hard left. Apply this filter to the S channel and its 100Hz fundamental will sound like it’s coming out of the right side. But the top end of the tom will still sound like it’s coming from the left.

Very extreme example, but seen this happen IRL more than once. Easiest to hear this on headphones if you’d like to experiment.

I’ve found the easiest way to avoid this is to use very gentle M-S slopes (gentle = less phase shift), shelves and bells, and especially avoid any steep HPF or LPF (18 dB/oct or greater).

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@BoozleBAM This is a GREAT question, and having read the whole convo twice I don't think it was really answered. Honestly I probably won't be able to answer it either, but here are some thoughts in no particular order

First the usual caveat, I'm not a mixer and I haven't mixed a record in a decade. But I did record and mix for 20 years before that and followed the whole arc from beginner not understanding compression, to pro finding my way and getting to own or use all of the baller dream hardware. All that to say I have a lot of empathy for where you are at with it. These are not definitive statements, just aspects to think about..

1) First something of a hot take that I don't see represented online. IMO compression often makes an individual instrument sound "worse". If you play and record something like drums well or acoustic guitar well, a compressed version will often sound *less real* and less vital. So why in the world would we do it???

- The first reason is that we mostly don't care about how individual instruments sound, we care about the whole song. Often a compressed sound will play nicer in an arrangement than something dynamic, real and recorded in a "documentarian" way

- The second reason is a trade off that isn't often spoken about. Compressed instruments often translate better into the wild. Take a beautiful, dynamic, real sounding, hifi & documentarian recording of say upright bass, drums and acoustic guitar. Listen in your studio in great monitors and it's a dream. Now go to Target and play it in mono on the overhead speaker on a busy saturday.....it just won't survive ... the song gets lost. Or drive with your window open, or cook dinner with the AC on etc etc.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Yep Rob just mixed Church. It was already taking off so they let it be as it was, then had Schepps do the rest.


I started out as an intern with Rob for a year in Dublin just after the Hozier album, and I remember him saying how when he got the mixes back, for a moment he thought he’d been sent the wrong files - the mixes felt the same, they just sounded better.

I learned so much from him and his approach to record making. Was actually thinking about how well he paces sessions when the convo about keeping artists “under control” came up.

He’s an amazing story teller, and has an infinite well of classics from his time with U2, Eno and Flood. He would alternate between having everyone in the room totally focused on getting their take or the part or whatever, then lift that pressure completely off with a hilarious story. Everyone would get to take a mental break, then after that pause they’d be ready to go full bore again. I’ve never seen albums come together as smoothly and painlessly as the ones I’ve worked on with him.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Doing tracks for live-show is a different beast than making a record. 

The impact and immersion of a record vs the live show are also different beasts. The art of the live show must include the spirit of the record, knowing that’s what the audience knows, but also must elevate it or mutate in a way to make that live show tantamount, at least for the people in the room that night. The “Yeah but have you seen them live?” question is the goal of every artist (and music director) but that’s always gonna be an exclusive subset of fans with real buy-in. 

As a producer, and an MD, (who’s also been an artist,) I firmly believe the studio and the stage are unique mediums, and that each should inform, without ever hindering, the other.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
I am super nerdy / obsessive about single coil hum, here are the tricks I’ve found:
- all my single coil guitars have been shielded - you should get a pickguard shield and also get the cavities shielded with copper. Puisheen on YouTube (mikes guitar bar) has a great tutorial. This will cost about 10$ per guitar and make a big difference.
- computer monitors can be a big culprit, especially older Apple Cinema displays. You kinda have to right facing direction with the guitar, usually 90 degrees from the screen. Think of single coils like figure 8 microphones, you want the screen in the null.
- ground loops can also be a big problem. I had this buzz going on DI guitars and most of my unbalanced synths - turns out one of my midi interfaces was creating a ground loop, you can get a ground lifting usb adapter. In my case I have balanced power at the studio and different phases (not sure if that the correct English term) but basically any USB hub is now on a different circuit then audio stuff and that removed a lot of buzz. On that topic, if you are using pedals make sure you have a good isolated power supply.
- last but not least: a proper guitar setup will help, if your pickups are too low, the signal to noise ratio will decrease. That being said I think I kinda like my pickup height a little lower than standard but that is just a taste thing.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’d like to unpack this for a bit, cause this resonates, and I’ve had long conversations with my mentors about it. 

Also, as someone who’s heard a fair bit of your work, I can say with my whole mouth that your output is EXCELLENT. 

1) a lot of the records we love were painstakingly put together by teams of people over long periods of time. We’re banging out productions all by ourselves in a small room at breakneck speeds. 

2) when you’re responsible for the writing, recording AND performing, and *then* the mixing, there’s no possible way to achieve the perspective required to ever feel like it’s a masterpiece.  

3) and perhaps most important: our ears are always going to be better than our craft. We’ve been listening to music for so long, and even as we continue to learn the craft our ears continue to grow as well. I think that’s part of the thing that makes making music so beautifully elusive, so satisfying and unsatisfying. It’s the thing that keeps us chasing. 

4) always looking for the next thing to help unlock the next thing is a great mindset AS LONG AS we remember there’s no silver bullet. Never was and never will be. 

I’ll get off my soap box now.

author: cian riordan

when it comes to frequency response of a monitoring setup, i think people way over estimate the contribution of the speaker and way under estimate the contribution of the room.

i just spent two days working on the monitoring in my new spot. one day with @cian riordan and one day with the unfuck guys. the room was built by some professional person with a floated floor and cloud and non parallel walls etc etc, and the imperfections are ALL in the room.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Lotsa great thoughts here from everyone, of course. I have a feeling you know all this tho- and what you actually need is perspective… either time away or listening with someone else in the room to reveal where the issues are, and the solutions that come with. 

If you don’t have time or people you trust to help get that perspective, try muting shit in the verses or interludes or choruses or posts, see what you can & can’t live without. If every part matters, than saving the very top & bottom for the choruses is a good move. 
I was always focused on stereo field, but going taller on the choruses is also on my Must list. 

And finally, detailing moments is truly where my heart is- so I love figuring out how to make every element that leads to the downbeat create the feeling of pregnant inevitably. Sometimes a super modded verb throw or a reverse that mutes right before the downbeat… somehow making things fall apart like a nude descending the staircase, then snap back together for the next downbeat… 
Assuming you’re mixing your own productions, the world’s your oyster. But even if your not, go Fucken nuts and see what the client says. IME, 9/10 they’re looking for your creativity too…. 
Tl;dr, you got this, you just need a nap.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I hope we can preempt any need to defend your own approach here. When we pull apart ideas, it’s never about pulling down the scaffolding that holds us up, but sometimes things we think are holding us up are holding us back. 

As an example- I was firmly entrenched in the idea that I should be able to great work on shit speakers. Amazing records were made on KRKs right? 

A friend of mine, the one who turned me onto LWMR, had better monitors than I had but he was obsessed with upgrading. I told him, in probably kinder words than this, “if you can’t make records on these speakers you probably just can’t make records.”

A couple weeks later, the Grammy winning mix engineer I was assisting told me “ehhh, you could probably do with an upgrade.”

That one sentance ultimately cost me close to $10,000, but that not only paid for itself in time saved along the way, but in the pure joy of making music. 

Again, not suggesting your approach is wrong, just a reminder than being right is less important than learning new shit.

author: ALXCPH
content:
theres so many ways to interpret this question. so here's my take. Mixing to me at least, is all about bringing out the intent of the record to the best of your abilities. Fx. if you are mixing a Classical record, all you aim for is probably getting something as close to being in the room as possible, and therefore fidelity. If you are mixing some new urban underground cultural music, you want to respect the grittiness as that can sometimes be part of the sound and/or culture, and you never want to remove the inherent DNA of what makes that thing exciting(even tho it might be unconventional). So in the end, it's OUR job to make the decisions on when to be rough and when to be high fidelity. It's all about what you want out of the music. For most mainstream music(aka. radio oriented) i would personally get a bit of both. Get the mix sounding somewhat exciting as to pull in the listener, but also have certain aspects be high fidelity as to make it easy to listen to. FX, in a pop record, Vocal intelligibility is super important if you want people to sing along, where are in a techno track or hyperpop track you can have some grittier vocals, as they aren't as intended to be the in the car sing along song. They would be much more about the energy and feeling. 

IMO theres nothing more boring than a perfect mix, where every sound is perfectly inline and has no personality that makes it memorable. 

The creativity of a mix is just as, if not more important, than the technicals. Thats what those cyborgs called Mastering Engineers are for.

The sleeper modulation plugin for me is the (free!) *Valhalla SuperMassive*. It's meant for huge, expansive delays and verbs, but if you turn down the delay time to the < 50ms range, and turn up the feedback it gives an effect that's somewhere between a chorus and room sound. Blend to taste.

author: sethmanchester
content: I used to do consistent audiobook work 15+ years ago to supplement studio work. It was brutal work and I hated it. RX didn’t exist yet, or was in it’s infancy and sounded terrible. I’d record and edit, used an m930 because of the low self noise which was huge for me around the time. My editing trick was to make a 5 min room tone loop the length of the book, duplicate the dialog, strip silence one track, using the dup track as a trigger to extract silence for the other track with the room tone selected, delete the dup track. In object mode select all the audio then it’s something like shift + drag to fill the gaps from strip silence with the extracted room tone. Always used beat detective to do batch cross fades. Then listen through and correct to taste. RX declick would have been a game changer back then but I did all that shit by hand, if there was a pop on a word you’d aim to find a similar syllable somewhere else to replace it with. At the time I was getting paid $250/finished hour for editing and $300 for tracking which was really good considering I could edit around 1.5:1 but tracking was always closer to 3:1. Budgets started shrinking right around the advent of RX. When I started, there was always an engineer, producer and proofer in the room for tracking. All lunches paid for. After enough experience I was able to provide all three which made it pretty lucrative. But the industry changed and eventually it was just engineer and reader which put a lot of pressure on the engineer to produce and proof. The  publisher I worked with stopped paying for lunch then dropped my fee to $250/$200 then $225/$175 then $200/$150 and once it hit $175/$125 I saw the writing on the wall and vowed never to do it again. I will say it upped my Pro Tools keyboard speed tremendously and kept my studio afloat early on. The halycon days of audiobook production are long gone as far as finaces are concerned.

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: Adam Thein

My hot take on headphone EQ is I just let my brain handle it and learn the headphones.  Tried manual EQ, tried SoundID, and not a fan of Harman. Adding to this I'd rather change my headphones entirely moving forward and see how they translate than to bandage what I'm using and totally change the character.  But whatever gets results for the individual, go for it.

author: cian riordan
content: FWIW: I never use auto align and have only used time adjuster to move room mics a little further away for effect. If things aren’t sounding locked with a simple polarity flip, I’ll quickly try and tinker with a HPF on key drum elements (kick, snare, etc). After that, I’ll resort to mountain moving EQ or samples. If someone didn’t have the skills and/or thought to record their drum mics in phase, then it’s very likely they’re not worth going through brain surgery to salvage them. Get them doing the fundamentals and move on with the mix.

This is why I harp on bedroom guitarists vs recording vs touring guitarist. If you’re by yourself a big meaty full frequency tone is satisfying. author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Think of your mix like Russian nesting dolls - it’s actually 3’mixes in one. The baby version is for tiny speakers - laptop, phone, iPad etc - approximated by a 400 Hz hi pass

Next is your “normal” mix - has low end but like basic car, small stereo, decent TV etc 

And last is the full range - good headphones, club, good car

author: chrissorem
content: @Sam Segarra The way I think about reverb is  closer/further, and adding length. Room verbs and short verbs without pre delay or a small amount of pre delay are good for pushing a vocal back into the mix. And longer verbs  like halls and plates are good for adding length and if you want length and the vocal to feel forward at the same time add more pre delay.  So nothing to worry about but rather think about what you are trying to achieve with the two verbs.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This goes counter to a lot of the conventional wisdom here, but I’ve always found listening somewhere else, while doing something else, incredibly helpful. When mixing, I try to take  some time to take in music the way that most people do, which isn’t hunched in front of my expensive monitors in my treated room hyper analyzing the 4k. 

Yesterday I was asking my buddy Spencer who lives in Georgia about a drum edit, and I could hear him listening to the song through the phone and realized the vocals were too hot. 

Little things like that can help me recenter on what’s important.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If the reverb's there from production and has to stay:

- It doesn't always need to be heard, sometimes can just be felt
- Sometimes it can be drastically EQd
- Sometimes automated so it's clearly audible when there's space for it, and tucked when there isn't
- Sometimes complementary (but different!) mono ambiences panned around maintain more breathing room than a stereo ambience that might blur the center. Tchad Blake is very good at this sort of thing.

If the reverb's coming from me, added in the mix, and it's not working quickly, I'll take a second and consider whether I've been barking up the wrong tree

author: Deleted User
content: At a certain price point(up to 2-3k€) I probably would reach for a dynamic mic or ribbon, speaking very generally. A dynamic can be cool to minimize room engagement, which can be great if the singer is loud and the room isn’t great. David Bock’s paper on capsules is really enlightening. I would definitely try and avoid a chinese capsule a la Rode mics, but the mic amp is also very important. I’d avoid condensers that have intense artifacts at high SPL because of their mic amp circuits(Brauner Phantom and the Neumann TLM series come to mind). It can be quite hard to find a condenser that has that vintage-U47 style body under a certain level of investment, which is why I might reach for a large-diaphragm dynamic or a ribbon(and boost highs). I’d what that low-mid body to balance out the density in the high mids. But I’m mostly talking about belly tenors here, with Betty female singer I would probably be fine with something with less body(like a U67-style mic) It’s quite an in-depth topic I find, you can hit me in the dms if you have specific questions.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Surprise surprise ima jump in with some Brauer bullshit again- zooming out of the vocal for a second, cuz I think the choices you’re talking about making, when made in a vacuum, can lead you to very different places depending on what you’re already hearing when you start adding vox fx. 

The idea is to identify the 2 or 3 things that the brain can actually focus on at any given moment in a song as the leading roles. Song I was on the other day had horns, vocal, and occasionally gtr were leading and everything else was just supporting (either octaves of the same part, rhythmically the same, or pads on keys). So I got those 3 rocking together without worrying about every track, it was easy to identify the kind of space I needed. I wanted it in the same room as the brass, but really forward on the stage. If I’d had the pads up while trying to do this I was always either too wet or too dry and couldn’t find the happy place. The tl;dr is, if you’re struggling to find a satisfying construction of ideas, you may be trying to treat leading and supporting parts as equally important, and you’re challenging your ear to grab what’s really important at that moment. 

Also in Brauer’s template there are a folder of verbs that everything in the session shares including vocals. So you get a sense of cohesion from that, and the vocals have their own folder of delays that are unique to them. That helps create separation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well if it's a sequenced track where I can be very pliable with the tempo one thing I'll do is to slowly adjust the tempo up and down and listen to the spaces *in between* the notes. I'll observe how that affects the feel.

Going slower will open up some space between the notes and give them a little more sense of  weight. Sometimes going too fast will make things feel cramped, or it may give it some urgency. If the song is groove-oriented this has a massive effect on the feel. Go figure.

Get up and dance. Observe your body and ask yourself how it feels. Does your body want to go quicker? Or does it feel better if it's laid back a bit? Imagine if the context that the song will be heard in. Is it a chill scenario? Or is it banging in a club where it might want some more push.

Sometimes the best tempo for a performance changes based on the acoustics of the room. Things like the pre-delay or tail are going to rhythmically inform you. And sometimes we key into the pulse that we feel from the echo in the room and conform to that implied rhythm.

It's kind of like how horn players will naturally discover the best sounding spot in the room for them if you allow them to wander around and play. Listen to the space and what it's telling you.

If I'm working with a live band I'll have them play to a click at a couple different speeds and ask them how it makes them feel. I'll have my own thoughts too, but getting the band thinking about it opens up fun conversations. Maybe they'll discover that Section A feels good at one tempo and then Section B is better if they speed it up a hair.

author: stefanmacc
content: This might be way overboard for your problem haha . But I had this issue on a mix that was sent to me… and what ended up working for me was to basically Re-amp the close mics one at a time into my live room through a speaker. And then lay a snare or kick drum against / on top of said speaker … and re record the decay of the new drum. It sometimes helped to roll off all the high and boost the low end of the shit re amp sound to get the drum to vibrate or move more air … and I was basically able to get real drums played exactly like the original but with the specific tone / decay I wanted. Then I would just blend these new recordings to taste …

author: cian riordan
content: Be realistic with what you’re working with. Both of those instruments are difficult to record properly, and featuring the acoustic nuance of a shitty sm57/Scarlett cello performance won’t do the song justice. I often find I’m compensating for un-ideal mic’ing in un-ideal rooms. I’m doing big midrange scoops to hash out resonances. Driving them into realistic spaces to get the dimension right. Sometimes saturating the source, sometimes saturating the space. The space is everything with orchestral instruments. Every now and then you get a good section in a great room playing a beautiful part and you don’t do a damn thing because it already makes the song.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

content:
You've already gotten some great replies, I'm a bit late to the party, but:

- I don't have a manager, or a regular assistant, and I don't use project management software. Just a doc of current projects
- I also mostly do one mix a day, sometimes two. Also do revisions later in the day
- Delivery timeline depends on who needs what and when. Dean Lewis + UMG + the full rate = tell me what you need, I'll get it done on time. Unsigned artists at the indie rate = still get the same attention and care, I'll move fast if I can, but I won't bump other work out of the way, won't wake up at 7am to go in early, etc.
- I prefer email but I'll do text or IG if the artist prefers. It is what it is. I have long since given up on "Inbox Zero."
- I keep a clear mind by (mostly) doing the work at my own pace, taking breaks when I want to, and not worrying too much about optimizing/organizing. Might not be the vibe for everyone, but my clients are happy and I never miss a deadline I've agreed to.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
As a mastering engineer, I’ve kept my monitoring level consistent for the past ten years—at a relatively low volume. This isn’t a rule, just my approach, and I do it because I know exactly how a finished track should sound in my room at that level.

Every system has a sweet spot, and if you can identify that in your setup, you’ll get more consistent results. This ties into factors like speaker and amp combinations, how your speakers push air—especially in the low end—and how they perform at different volumes.

Many speakers don’t reproduce low frequencies accurately when played too softly. On the flip side, when pushed too hard, speakers often cap the low end, meaning the bass stops getting louder while the mids and highs continue increasing. This is common in everyday listening setups—people crank their systems beyond their limits, causing an imbalance where the top end dominates.

This is one reason why working with a mastering engineer with a well-calibrated setup can be beneficial. But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to do things—some engineers work in less-than-ideal setups and still get great results. It all comes down to what works for you and gets you the sound you like.

One thing that’s important to remember which i amsure you already know.... your ears perceive frequencies differently at different volumes—this is a well-documented, non-linear effect. The way we hear balance changes with loudness, which is why understanding how your room and speakers respond at your chosen listening level can make a huge difference in achieving consistent, reliable masters. If you crank it... "memorize" in your ears how it should sound cranked. Then when you drop down to another level.."memorize" how it sounds there. You should then find a few spots you can use.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not sure if this is more #📺episode-talk, but there was chat in a recent pod about finding a good Audiomovers / remote mix notes session workflow. I've been having pretty smooth results since 2020 like this:


- Get clients on headphones (unfortunately a necessity for feedback/delay reasons, but I'm finding a lot of times that's how they listen to most music anyway, so they're very familiar with their headphones of choice). 

- Have them open your Audiomovers link.

 - Start a Facetime/Zoom call on your phone with whoever needs to be there. Mute your own Facetime mic on your phone, but clients leave theirs open. They'll hear your chat via the talkback mic you've set up in Tools.

 - Use talkback mic routing as pictured. If you're a Pro Tools nerd, you can probably work out what's going on by following the routing and sidechain assignments in the screenshot, but:


I print mixes and the limited ref (usually just tickling Pro-L 2) at the same time, so I make a Pre-Fade send to the Audiomovers bus from my Mix Print channel. This is also where the limiter lives, so their Audiomovers feed goes out at a healthy level.

My talkback channel (usually a 57) has a ducking compressor on it, sidechained from the Listen Print send and set to stun. This means my TB mic gets (more or less) muted during playback, so I can work on speakers while I make their tweaks. Muteomatic is still in my template, but I think I opted for the sidechained compressor because delay tails etc were getting double piped down to clients through my mic the moment playback stopped, whereas the compressor has adjustable release so it can come back up more or less as the tails die.

If any of that doesn't make sense, just lemme know and I can amend this post.

content:
I don’t know enough about screen tech to give an accurate answer but I’ve found this issue more precedent with Apple monitors than cheaper monitors… The luminosity has nothing to do with it, I think the screen emits RF. I think it’s just the reality of single coils, I’ve seen videos of John Mayer in the studio (who probably has all the resources available to take care of those issues) trying to turn slightly to find the best spot for noise… Here’s how I deal with it: 
- If the guitar is playing in a loud part of the arrangement: I don’t care and face wherever.
- If the guitar part I am playing is very sustained with little space for the noise to pop up: I don’t care and face wherever
- if it’s an electric guitar only intro or a quiet part or the noise is definitely heard: face in the best direction and I don’t hesitate to use a little bit of RX noise reduction if needed.

@Ross Fortune getting back to you late about your question of what do you do when you don't know what to do, but, I actually have something that really works for me that I want to share with you. Its really simple and kinda fool proof, and almost always works for me if my head is in the right space. I've said it before in here but saying again. 

Litterally just sit in your chair, and listen to music of the genre you're mixing, for like a half hour

And then when you go back to your mix session, listening at the same volume, it will become very very apparent what you need to do.

author: cian riordan
content: This “pre-gain staging your template” thing sounds like you’d be backing yourself into even more trouble. Templates are meant to be flexible and you’ll always need to make adjustments to make things work for the track. Let’s say you calibrate your drum bus for 1 dB of gain reduction — what does that do to account for the overall mean volume of those drums? The frequency density? It’s such a weird esoteric metric to try and quantify the signal you’re sending through it. Best thing you could do is setup your template to be able to do broad stroke gain adjustments within, very quickly, to get your chains hitting the way you like.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you've got the *Valhalla Supermassive* I like to make a faux room sound by cranking the *feedback* up to 75%, dialing the *delay time* down to around 9 ms and maybe *warp* at 50%. It's a much more synthetic, and chorus-y sound, but blends well with just about anything.

The cool thing about *Supermassive* is that there's so much heavy modulation on the delay lines that you don't get a lot of nasty ringing or notches that you'd get with most delays at that short of a delay setting.

author: Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If I'm totally rebalancing drums, I'll treat them as if I'm tracking them myself and building a basic working drum sound.This *usually* goes as follows, and I like to do it *very* quickly (as if the drummer is in the live room playing and everyone's waiting):

1. Mute everything.
2. Pull up kick in and out (+ sub or whatever they've recorded). Play with balance and phase of kick out until it feels good (good is context dependent - sometimes that's deep/subby/slow, sometimes that's punchy/percussive etc).
4. Bring up overheads along with kick mics. Flip overhead phase and play with balance til it sounds cool, or punchy, or whatever you're after. Sometimes there's a very obvious right or wrong answer, but often just figure out whatever works for the drum groove + arrangement + song. Where the bass sits can often help tell you what config will work best.
5. Solo snare mics, get them in phase with each other (just listen together and flip usually snare bottom until the blend sounds cool to you - often I'm looking for whichever configuration has more "thud", but that's context dependent). 
6.Unsolo and check snares against kicks and overheads. If you need to flip the snares, flip both top and bottom (or whatever combo) together so their relative phase remains intact. 
6. Add in rooms, again flipping and balancing til shit feels cool. Do same for crush mics, any other flavour stuff.

Toms are usually my last concern. Unless the groove is tom heavy, they might do only 2 or 3 hits across the whole song, so as Ryan said - hand gate those fuckers and deal with them once the general sound is dialled in.

I see - what I’m thinking is maybe this step could be working against you - you are essentially forcing all your mics to sum perfectly and you might be ending up with having to do massive eq moves on things that maybe would have naturally been phasing out in a pleasing way for a live room recording.

I’d strongly consider turning off your AA2 plugs on anything that aren’t drums unless it makes it sound significantly worse to you.

I’m a big fan of AA2 but it’s always case by case.  Sometimes the natural phase of the mics can be closer to the result you are looking for eq wise than the perfectly time aligned and phase rotated ones.

author: James Redfern
content: The original use I found for it years ago was on drum shells, turning the knob to the left acted as a sort of very smooth gate. You could get rid of cymbal schmutz in the top-end/midrange, but let the fatness of the snare decay a little more naturally, or maybe there’s a midrange ringing I don’t want, but I like that frequency on the initial attack, etc. over time it’s just become a tool I turn to for all sorts of stuff. Want the mids of a reverb to decay longer? Want to control the length of certain qualities in room mics? Etc

author: cian riordan

author: Slow Hand
content:
So I'm hearing two things: You're having difficulty knowing how to get what you want (over or under processing) and you're not feeling confident about the choices that you're making.

If you hadn't already mentioned it, my first thought would be to evaluate your monitoring because it sounds as if you're missing the mark that you're aiming at (over/under processing). But it also sounds like you are split on the target that you're trying to hit in the first place.

When the production you're given to mix is lacking in some way - maybe the sonics aren't great, the arrangement isn't great, or the song is not great - there can be an urge as mixer to want to close that gap by delivering a killer mix. Sometimes we see that gap and think that we'll be able to make this record amazing and make up for it's shortcomings by crushing the mix. But there's only so far that we can take a song at the mix stage. Maybe the record will be great anyways despite some perceived issue.

While there's always room for improvement take care that you're not putting all of that weight on your shoulders. By all means do a great job, but know when to stop chasing an unattainable goal. It's not necessarily something that you can resolve as mixer. So - if that's the case - make sure you're not demanding the world from yourself.

author: jerikcenteno
content:
OH! Thought of two more things that I feel is important to add that ppl might find helpful....

Definitely strip silence/cut out silences in the non-talking audio to get rid of the noise floor, coughs, etc. I do this by hand rather than the strip silence function since the function in PT might delete stuff I didn't want deleted.

At the company I freelance at, they heavily use this app called Descript. You upload your VO's and it builds out a transcript for you. You then can edit the transcript and it'll chop up the audio accordingly. It works better when the VO's are isolated/have no bleed and not recorded in the same room because bleed can mess up the transcription, but if Descript is analzying just one VO at a time, it works great. Then, you can export an .aaf and upload into PT to make fades, mix, etc. Check it out! I've used it too and it's kinda crazy. Prob the only useful AI thing I've come across. 

https://www.descript.com/

author: Iwan Morgan
content: @sinaigimenez You can go very scientific with this, but first thing I would do is find a handful of your favourite tracks and play them back at a level where you feel comfortable in your room - not too loud that it hurts, but feels relatively balanced.  Then use a quick SPL Meter in C weighted mode (loads available for iphone) and see where the SPL lands when playing back these tracks.  In my room it's around 75-80 db and I'm comfortable there.  I know that when I leave my monitor controller at my predetermined setting playing back mastered -9>Lufs tracks roughly how it should sound.  if something sounds dark/bright it's usually because it is.  Like wise if a vocal is too quiet, I'm not reaching for the main volume pot to turn the overall mix up, I'm turning the vocal up until it feels right.  And also, if my mix isn’t feeling loud enough or present enough at the preset monitoring level I know I need to work harder to get it to sit in the same world as the refs.  Once you get your head around it, it’s very freeing.  I use Metric Halo Monitor controller directly connected to my speakers and control via a Stremdeck (thanks @Bryan DiMaio !) and this has 5db volume steps where I know I can mix without my limiter at +10 and when the limiter is engaged I need to be back at 0. I imagine the Hilo has something similar?

Treat yourself like a producer who sent you a track to mix—it doesn’t matter how messy it is, you gotta freeze everything and simplify your life. I’m working on a pop record for one of my favorites clients and before I went into mix it, we were at about 100 tracks and it nearly ate me alive until I started removing the excess that was driving me insane. For instance, all the backing vocals can probably become one track by now rather than one group, your leads can become one if they’re close enough, etc.

Make copies of previous saves, but honestly commit to your production choices, take time away from the track, and be honest with your client about the fact that you’ll need a little more time than normal due to the irregularity of mixing your own production.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Got a question for my Audio DSP nerds: Does convolution of two audio signals introduce phase shift?

Convolution is most often used for reverbs, where phase shift is acceptable. But what if you convolved your audio signal with a fixed EQ curve that is 1 sample in duration?

As we all know, using a normal EQ imparts phase shift around those frequency bands, and an EQ curve with *lots* of bands, is likely to be a big, smeary, mess that distorts your phase relationships.

What if you took a big complicated EQ curve (like the type that you'd see on a Sonarworks correction curve), sampled that, and then used it with a convolver plugin to re-apply that same complex filter to your mix buss? Would this method sidestep the phase shift that you get from using traditional EQ bands?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Convolution is a strange technique to describe in a way that is intuitive to understand. But here goes:

In convolution you have two audio signals, your *input signal* and your *impulse response*. The simplest description of what convolution does is that it multiplies the *input* signal by the *impulse* signal and what it spits out is a new audio signal that includes only the frequencies and amplitude values that both signals have in common.

Practically speaking, what this means is that when you convolve an *input* (let's say, a full frequency drum kit recording) with your *impulse* (let's say a 5 ms burst of white noise that was hi-passed at 500 Hz). What you end up with is a drum recording that sounds like it was hi-passed at 500 Hz.

Think of it like how a vocoder works (which isn't that different). Your vocoder might combine a full-frequency synthesizer patch (input) with the frequency contours and time content of your voice (impulse/carrier). But if your voice doesn't have 100 Hz in it then we never hear the 100 Hz from the synth patch because the input and carrier/"impulse" don't share that frequency. What you hear is what both signals have in common. If your voice has a huge peak at 1.5k, then the synth patch is going to be accentuated in that same way.

So. What I'm saying is that if I have a complex EQ curve (ala Sonarworks corrective EQ) that I use as my *impulse response* and convolve it with, say, the output of my stereo buss, will it impart that frequency curve onto my mix *without* the phase shift that you'd get from a traditional FIR or IIR filter (aka traditional EQs)?

In short, I don't know because it's hard to search for the answer online. But I'm throwing a hail mary in case we've got any DSP nerds in the forum.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got some ideas for you. 
1) if your gain staging is done properly, you’ll notice when the low end starts to interact negatively with the rest of the frequency bands. 
2) reference reference reference. Listen to songs with the kind of low-end you’re looking for and reference them diligently.
3) have someone you trust that can tell you how it’s going when you think you’re getting close. I got a road rig together for mixing, expecting that I’d get 70% there before finishing in my studio. Surprisingly I got closer to 95% just using good techniques ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 
4) its like anything else, the more you do it, the better you get at it. 

I hope this helps. Andrew Scheps is on headphones now and he seems to be real happy. You might be able to find some good insight from him.

Also keep in mind I do mostly Country Music and bedroom pop, which aren’t necessarily the most bass heavy genres.

Flipping between sections doesn’t do it for me, and it’s not how any listener is going to experience the flow of the song. It makes sense that Tony and Jon are so dedicated to mixing the song from the top every time.

If I’m really doubting my perspective, I’ll turn the monitors down so low I can hardly hear the song and see that I can still understand every lyric. Usually pretty easy to tell at low volumes that the vocal is getting buried in the chorus.

author: ALXCPH
content:
That is true, but I think a good mix still sounds bad in target 😅 and I’ve been in enough bars and restaurants that have playback systems that sound worse than my iPhone in a bathroom only playing out the left speaker. 

And people will still say, “omg I love this song” and start bouncing their head.

 I believe that great songs translate every and anywhere. But fidelity cannot IMO be appreciated in these specific places. 

Ofc there are exceptions. But try eating at a restaurant on a beach promenade in south Spain and the restaurant next to you has a speaker 20 inches from your head blasting a different song. And tell me you think the vocal is warm or the drums are punchy. I think, sadly for general non music fans what they find in music, is less quiteness it’s not even about the song. 

Whereas I think the people who enjoy music, will appreciate that extra punchy drum sound or warm vocal and deep bass. And I believe those people use headphones 80% of the time. They might have a great speaker system at home. But how much time do we really have at home listening to said speakers? Headphones are with us on the go all the time. Everyone I know under 30. Listens primarily on headphones. Or their iPhone speaker. Sometimes a JBL at the beach or park, and every now and then a party speaker at a party while drunk. The ones who really really love music, either have an old vintage speaker set from their parents or a Sonnos/smart speaker type thing. 

I still believe mixing for speakers is important, and @Nomograph Mastering has a great point in speakers translating to headphones easier than vice versa. But I always make sure shit sounds amazing on my AirPods. I’d rather sacrifice something in the speaker than the AirPods. But then again. I don’t have the accolades you do. So I might be shooting myself in the foot. But that is my general philosophy.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If it's really upsetting me I might deal with it early, but I prefer to live with those details as I get the drum mix together - there's (usually) going to be bus compression, maybe added fake Oceanway room, samples and their idiosyncracies - so many variables, all often getting processed on drum bus (+ potential parallels per song section).

By the time I'm done with that it usually just feels more like a general vibe than an exercise in precision - the snare ring in the left room mic might draw the ear away from the kick flam in the right (or that flam could now groove in a cool way as the comps breathe, or it slaps against a rhythm guitar part or whatever), but I can always go back and Time Adjuster (or L/R EQ with Fab or whatever) the rooms if they're really bothering me.

Same reason I don't usually address snare rings until I've got the drums working well

author: Ross Fortune
content:
And I totally agree on only doing what sparks joy. I’ve wholly accepted that my only consistent motivator is loving what I’m doing in each moment. 

In every aspect of my life - work, relationships, any decision - any time I’ve gone against my gut and done *anything* for the wrong reason, it’s come back to bite me ten fold. 

I still think the above is a reasonable thought exercise though. We’re artists and creators and all that, but as it stands for most of us we’re businesses too, and human beings. It’s a positive thing to reflect on experience and evaluate potential future positions, if only to be certain you don’t want to go down particular roads. My actual life experience has just been to do what I like to do, and that’s guided me, but maybe there’s room for forward thinking so we don’t wind up down holes we don’t want to be in.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I always work at the same level. Largely comes from my days working as a scoring mixer and in film music where everything is done at the calibrated levels. That’s what I still use. System gets calibrated at 80dBSPL, film mixing (which I don’t do much anymore) gets done at 0, other mixing at a slightly reduced level, mastering at -12, and Atmos mastering at -6. Computer output is -12 unless I’m watching something like Netflix or listening to surround music in which case it’s 0. All done through Totalmix presets. For listening to music etc I adjust the level and it’s usually pretty quiet but for any work I click the button to load a snapshot and then don’t touch the level

author: Rollmottle
content:
the case is the same digital or analog. it's a helpful tool to keep your gain staging in check. the key is what you calibrate the meter to and where you place it. 

it seems particularly useful on making sure you're hitting known processing chain inputs in their sweet spot. put the meter before any bus processing chain and calibrate the meter to its sweet spot. now you know quickly when you're hitting (or not hitting) the spot where you know it can do the thing in the way you expect it to do the thing. the other really useful one is post bus processing. set the meter on a bus output calibrated to a target level, now you know how gain decisions within the bus are or are not getting you where you want to be. for those working in templates and mixing into known bus processing chains, it seems like it would take a lot of the guess work out of gain staging decisions. it's a very broad stroke tool, but helps me very quickly make decisions on what level something needs to be juiced up or down to. just takes a little upfront work.

author: Edward Rivera
content: I'm the worst with fx. So it's pretty standard. Always have mono and stereo reverbs set up, along with mono and stereo  1/4 and 1/8 delays. And Microshift for when that's needed. Also a slap back delay and infinite reverbs but that's pretty rare. Maybe a mono spring or chamber if it's a vintage thing. And a short room if I want reverb that you don't "hear". All my delays also have sends to my vocal reverbs so they aren't so sharp sounding.

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Honorable Mention) Squarepusher - Ultravisitor**

I wouldn't even consider this a live album. In some ways it's as far from live as you can get, but Tom does this really cool thing across the album: he switches back and forth between the feeling of being at a live show and listening to a studio record.

*Tetra-Sync* is a great example. It begins sounding like you're standing in the audience watching him perform and it seamlessly melts away into a full studio production over the course of a few minutes. As if you closed your eyes at a show and when you opened them you're lying on the floor at home with headphones and have no recollection of how you arrived there.

There's this great blink-and-you'll-miss-it moment when the live jazz kit seamlessly switches from being played to being programmed: https://open.spotify.com/track/5TwlEMyRImfmgDbXWNkRLd?si=72fb59fd9cef4fbb

Yeah so x/y isn’t great for info on the sides for a solo performance. It’s more about capturing more of the guitar, the string chime and the body. It’s a little wider than a mono mic so it works well as a single instrument with a vocal, but it’s not gonna do a “stereo” thing. 

My best advice out the gate is keep it about 6-8” off the 10th feet and move around until the balance feels right. If you’re missing brilliance, try raising the guitar or leaning left or right a little… it’s really about your instrument and your room and which mics you’ve got. 

Honestly x/y should be an easy way of getting the full guitar captured.

author: Edward Rivera
content:
If you have room mics, you're going to want to delay them in order to simulate the heard experience of the instrument in that room. The mic itself will capture the sound signature of the ambience, but the delay will give the perception of that ambience. 

Think of a drum kit in a room, and you've got a room mic on the far end of said room. The sound of the drum is going to travel across the room and into that mic, but it needs to travel _back_ to the drummer in order to be perceived. That's what the delay will do

author: Rob Domos
content: Voices in room do not sound like they are hitting a microphone. Think about the physics of sound for a second. High frequencies move in a laser beam shape and low frequencies move in a spherical shape. Nobody is ever turning with their ear facing 1 foot from a mouth that is laserbeaming high end into their ears. This is why you almost never hear saliva drips and lip smacking when in conversation and hear it constantly in recordings. This is also a big reason why the high end of most captures sounds so rough and edgy compared to real life. A lot of what I’m doing is going in and massaging that high end to take it from “this sounds like a mic capsule” to “this sounds like the person is in the room”

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: iampedrorafael
content: Same situation here, I used to avoid the "reality check" at the beginning of the mix so I could move primarily by feel. But then I was consistently making macro EQ moves on the mix bus in order to match the references a bit more at the end of the mix (typical 2db presence boost, maybe some 200-300hz scoop). This was a real pain in the ass, cause naturally things change a bit at that point and it's not an effective way to handle the problem. So now I have a preset for MetricAB with 8 reference tracks ready to go that I listen for short periods of time, sometimes 5 seconds or so, just to keep my years calibrated to what "normal" feels like in a macro-level. The fact that I don't need to leave the DAW environment (changing the visuals as well) to open a streaming app with different stimulus makes it really convenient to just do the right thing and compare apples to apples. The band-isolation mode really helps me to compare how different frequency ranges are moving also

author: Slow Hand
content:
I find it's rarely necessary to compress a synthesizer if you're the one programming it. You already have control over the attack/sustain ratio on the instrument using the ADSR controls. And you can balance the harmonics through your choice of filtering or oscillators. Synthesizers rarely have low-level information to be revealed that can't simply be turned up at the source.

Of course, you might want the distortion artifacts from compression, but I'd probably use a saturator module.

That said, if you're a mixer who has received an audio bounce of a synth, then... sure! Compression would be good for balancing poke-y stuff, controlling boomy low-end, or there could be some room tone from a re-amp signal, or some attack that needs to be accentuated. So compress away!

One more additional thought on LCD-X for travel - they aren’t something I’ve ever felt comfortable tossing into a backpack loose and they are heavy and bulky. I’ve also gotten used to running them with an EQ to fill in the 2800hz dip, which makes taking them around tougher as a plug n play travel option. APM I personally trust less for work as a reference with my ears but the pros outweigh the cons so heavily and they have a high utility outside of work as a travel headphone.

author: Maxim
content:
I mean without music in context there's not a ton to say. And even if you managed to get the room out of the vocal (which with plugins like RX 8/9, C-VOX, SPL De-Verb, etc. is still not great) I doubt you'd be left with much that's "nice" to work with. 

But nevertheless, after doing some processing with the usual tools (best mentioned above - look into the new Dialog Isolate from RX 9) my intuition would be to eq the lower mids/lows first in the context of the music to get rid of the room "mud". 

Then maybe (lightly) slap some Soothe or Gullfoss on there to see what that does. Then once you've possibly got something to work with, go through the usual steps you might process a vocal with  (more additive/tone-shaping tools to get a sound).

Thing is, if you don't have all these plugins already it would be much cheaper to just record a better vocal. (I think you can demo them all though?) Maybe even consider renting a studio for a day (if the artist has the budget).

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is a very complex question. 

The closer you get at the beginning to a finished sounding product, the easier each phase gets. More time/effort spent arranging the song, less time recording. More time/effort recording, less needed for mixing, etc. But there just isn’t always the time to make things that “perfect” when you’re in the room with folks producing or writing, etc. 

A conversation on here that was an eye opener: a finished mix should be 99% complete sounding before going to mastering. I wouldn’t intentionally leave a lot of decisions up for the mix phase. 

Honestly, there’s two ways you can go about this. You can revise the production and recording to get it where you want, take as much time as it takes. Or you can try to mix the hell out of it and move on to your next project. There’s always more songs. Finishing is incredibly important.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not totally sure. I don’t think metering is going to help you. I’d avoid a mix by numbers approach. Maybe your monitoring needs some attention. A bad room can really make it painfully hard to make confident decisions that translate in the moment or even later in mixing.

Templates to me speed up your workflow not necessarily help you make better decisions if that makes sense. It’s like, setting up several busses you ALWAYS make, so instead of doing 100 keystrokes and commands to get your busses and FX built, two clicks and they’re there for you.

I don’t know what genre / style / level you’re working at, but I’d say just keep working at it. I love recording music because you can ALWAYS do it again. Time is the only thing you have to lose. With enough time, anything is possible. 

That said, looking at a frequency analyzer of a whole mix you like isn’t a horrible thing to do. Maybe you’ll see your mix is way too dark, or way too thin simply.

author: ehutton21
content: This used to be a weak spot of mine and to be fair I think everyone constantly fights these kind of battles. I recommend putting your mix in mono from the jump for a while and heavily rely on filtered listening (so NS10s or mixcubes) as you gain stage and make yourself get the sound good in mono. It feels like 101 level stuff at times but if you’re not forcing things to mono and isolating ranges, you’re not forcing yourself to make the real big EQ strokes. That’s why I love my cubes—I gotta be bold and decisive to be big on cubes.

author: ehutton21
Will Melones
content:
I’m starting to believe I’m not as good at treating vocals as I thought I was. Usually the stuff I get to mix is recorded in a bedroom or worse on a cheap condenser mic, and I’ll do what I can to polish the turd, but at some point it’s as good as it can get.

But then I listen to some of the previous releases some of these artists have, and I wonder if the folks who mixed those songs had to work with the same quality raw material. The stuff sounds pro in the end (sometimes).

It seems like this is more and more the way things will be for good. It’s rare that someone is singing into a decent mic and pre in a treated room (studio!?) or that they bother with mic technique.

Does anyone have tips or resources related to *really* digging into the repair of things like wonky room resonances, harsh-ass mics, inconsistent distance, and sometimes no talent? It seems like the folks working in that next level up can wave a magic wand and turn an NT1A into a 251 without harshness or dullness.

I always thought vocal recording was pretty clear cut. I guess I spoiled myself because all of the stuff I mixed early on I had recorded myself, and my only real ‘vocal’ mic was an RE20.

author: ehutton21
content:
Ahhh I see you’ve met my people—the bedroom artist! 

Jokes aside, I got into engineering because me and my friend could not afford to have someone decent mix our stuff, so I know the NT1A to 251 struggle well—he records exclusively on an NT1A. 

The biggest thing about working with bedroom-y vocals is they’re going to have their shortcomings, and maybe more so than most other mixes, you can process them quite a bit and you should. Do whatever RX work you need to do, and do that first. I don’t usually worry about playing the vocals with the track at this point, im just hunting for any pops, clicks, clips or room artifacts. 

Next for me is reamping—this may be odd to some people and their may not be a general consensus on how much it helps, but it gives me a sense of tonal consistency when I can set how I want the vocal to drive. If you have something that feels like how you would have tried to record it, it helps the psychological aspect IMO.

author: ehutton21
content: Yeah, it depends. I like room ambience match in RX if I need it and I mean we all know the slog of clip gain, pro-q, clipper, repeat. When it comes to taking something like wild resonances though I like tools that don’t make me overthink, and with soothe and multiband I gain tonal control I can’t gain otherwise

author: Slow Hand
content:
lol. Reminds me of this old Max/MSP device that someone made that compressed audio into something like 2 bits of dynamic range. You could end up with a truly flat audio file that had lost all sense of proportion. A sample of a door slamming in a house might go like this:

1. A tiny tick (door slamming)
2. A period of steady midrange (the room verb)
3. The whoosh of the entire noise floor and A/C unit rushing in to fill the vacuum. 😆

author: Adam Thein
content:
As someone who spends a lot of time in the no-crossfeed zone hearing a little shitty bandpassed speaker move a small amount of air helps me hear balance issues immediately.

The most major downside of headphones is translation to speakers.  You can make some crazy fun mixes that just don't translate.  I've tried the Canopener, Sonarworks, manual EQ, etc, and my best stuff is always a result of spending a lot of time referencing other mixes I know and love combined with a ton of car checks, speaker tests.

I can't wait for the day I have a space where I'm able to make noise, get some 310s and some treatment and stop chasing my tail and spend 3-4x the amount of time getting to where I want to go.  That's the hope anyway.

I'm not trying to deter anyone from getting started getting practice mixing in headphones, but it's definitely a stopgap for me and one I'm getting more and more fatigued by personally as the years go on.

author: popaganda.
content: A couple things - there are no “shoulds” in music. Play around until it sounds good. If you have trouble hearing the effects of different reverb settings I would just open up a session, maybe something you’ve already finished, and just play around with the verb settings and listen and see if you can create that sense of depth with early reflections predelay and decay. But my general stance is that if you can’t hear it it doesn’t really matter for this project, and if you want to hear it better you should do some experiments, stretch your ears out, and also maybe see if you need to deal with anything in your room or speakers that’s obscuring the perception of space.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Is the kick note decaying too slowly?  Like if it decayed faster would it be workable, or are you trying to find a way to move the pitch down?

I’d try a soothe sidechained to an original copy of the kick close mic(s) and try and get that to pull the kick’s decay off the room and overheads, then you can play with repitching the kick close mics depending on bleed or combining with a volume shaper like the Cableguys thing or Duck or LFO Tool, something that can use the audio input as the detection circuit and try and shorten the kick as much as you can get away with and then if you have to layer in something like a clean sine wave gated to the kick to get the note you are looking for.

Definitely not without a lot of tradeoffs on the way but some combination of that has worked for me in the past in a pinch

author: Rollmottle
content: Use a VU meter on the HW out that is calibrated to the level you like to hit your HW. then there's no guessing how much gain you need to adjust something to next time you want to hit it.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Twas me...VU meters are very useful tools because of their relative nature. If you know where the sweet spot of a compressor is on a drum bus for example, you can calibrate 0 on the VU meter to that sweetspot. then mixing into your compressor isn't such a guessing game every time (because you get the needle bouncing around 0, not too far under or not too far over). 

i use a digital one on the way out when i'm hitting my analog chain so everything goes out at the relative same level. i use an analog one on the way back in calibrated to a "safe" level and i know when it's coming back in ultra hot or i need a little extra gain to get it to the sweet spot. when you're monitoring stays at a consistent level, VU meters can help you judge relative relationships quite easily. i could see it being useful in the use case you described if you've calibrated the VU accordingly. say you want to generally hit -10 at the mixbus...calibrate a -10 signal to 0 on the VU. everything you then feed into the mixbus will show on the VU + or - where you want to end up.

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A producer buddy of mine asked me yesterday how often I listen in mono while mixing. I said “When I find myself using too many stereo imagers to make things fit, sometimes I’ll check to see what kind of fuckery I’m causing. But honestly who listens in mono anymore?”

He reminded me a lot of small Bluetooth speakers are in mono, so I decided this morning to take a fresh look at a tune I’m producing/mixing, starting in mono. 

The leveling choices totally broke down when I switched to stereo, but I think the mix is much better and it happened faster cause I was forced to look at the eq in relation to the center elements, so even when I spread them back out there was more room for the vocal kik snare bass to speak. 

Y’all ever start a mix in mono? Or work with mono as a tool for extended periods?

author: Josh Bowman
content: If it’s a modern/pop/“competitive” (ugh I hate that word but you know what I mean) genre how I deal with this in recent years is to make sure the arrangement is doing the heavy lifting instead of actual volume to get the feeling of dynamics, instead of making the song too dynamic (ie quiet parts too quiet). I always do a quiet listen or a headphone city walk to see if I loose important elements in the quiet bits to make sure I don’t overshoot the dynamics. Also don’t get stuck in a loop of just one section for too long. Also sometimes I start the intro a little louder and slowly let the volume settle to where I actually want it in the verse if I want it to actually be a bit more dynamic… just a subtle bump of the intro guitar/piano etc then let it settle under the vocal can help it appear loud enough in a playlist off the top and still let you have some contrast from verse to chorus. I know I said two conflicting things- depends on the arrangement

author: river
content:
As I like to mix loud, I take inspiration from a method I found called "clip to zero" when it comes to returns/buses/groups (I'll name them buses.)
And also Skrillex and his crazy groups. He showed his screen for a music video a while ago so it's prolly changed but still gave me inspiration.

It'll look something like
Drum bus + drum room bus, grouped together = drum sum bus.
Synth bus  + synth FX bus = synth sum bus
Vocal bus + vocal fx bus = vocal sum.

If it calls for it and I'm feeling spicy, have another group which contains just my bass elements as their own sum group.

Depending on the track, and how important I think any single element is over the other, I might do something like further group/bus together my drums and synths. Leaving me with 2 buses to balance against each other.

author: Edward Rivera

author: chrissorem
content: An fx return is simple. Think of this. I have an echo chamber. I’m sending the vocal to a speaker in the echo chamber and I’m recording  the echo in the room with a mic. So, take a mono synth and put it center, but then take the reverb and put it right. Or take a guitar room mic and put it right for close mic, but grab the stereo room mics and pan them R and C. Or two close mics on two cabs and pan them L and C. Here’s a graphic he sent me that helped it click:

author: spectrummasters
content:
fwiw, im in a good position to experiment currently as i get quick money on site and then have the time where i dont have the recall/revisions/deadlines workflow demands that most talented / industry people here do, so i  have taken the last year out to spend a lot of time thinking, learning and planning how to offer something fresh as a mixer here in Lonoon and i dont want to sound like anyone else. So ,im ditching gullfosses and soothes and spectral shapers and MB's..and im breaking my buses out to h/w mixers and boxes so that i can hopefully induce some electromagnetic phenomena or some "accidental" errors , like  my two year old coming in and turning knobs on the gear without me seeing (as he does) and then i mix through it , unknowingly....and ive introduced something wrong, something a perfect alogirthm could never give me ....something........difffffferent. Im v. bored atm with listening to perfect productions and mixes. Imho they are delicious and tasty and  malnourishing like McDonalds.

Imho, the sound of  Robert Johnson recorded, singing crossroads in a shack somewhere a 100 years ago will still outlast the bombastic incredibly perfect production/mixes i feel encouraged to mimic today. i feel like perfection has been overdone at this point. Lets f things up

it might be a naff idea but , where im at....since doing band stuff....that tom elmhirst quote about there being no perfect mix....and the mix is the mix that happened at the moment where eevryone in the room agreed was it......and not to be touched again...this is what im fascinated with at the mo....and doing the print with me and the drummer on my current mixes pushing the analogue faders (with the busses stemmed out of the daw) together. Making it performative and transient

author: bobby k
content: i've dealt with this a fair amount, but never thought to mention it here. For better or worse, I often end up with pretty air-tight first passes on the gainstaiging front. So sometimes, when a mix note is as simple as "turn up 808", the rest of the mix changes for obvious reasons. I'm hitting my multiband different, hitting my clipper different, hitting my limiter different; so if I were to simply execute that note, now the vocal, guitar, pretty much everything shifts a good bit in energy and I then spend time making the mix work again now that a big chunk of energy got pushed up in it. (side note - I like to mix a bit more gentle/tight on the low-end side since the lows are so hot in car systems, headphones, entertainment centers, etc. these days. Midrange is my home base.) Curious what your experiences have been with this sort of thing, and/or if you have recommendations.
