author: nachomaquieira
content:
I think it would be great if you could talk with the artist/producer, throwing out ideas and sort of a concept or direction from where to take the songs. From there, start working and take things in the direction you (or the team) feel is best.
It would also make sense for the sound/concept of the album to emerge as you progress through your mixes. It might click right away with the first track, or it might not fully take shape until you're working on the third song for ex. I think it's totally fine and part of the process. Communication with the artist and the producer is key here also, and this is also a great opportunity for you to have more room to shape that identity as you go. In these cases (where the sounds are less baked) it opens up creative opportunities worth exploring and pushing further

author: Jack
content:
Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

author: JustinLeu
content:
I also love consistency with monitoring levels…

I have a mix start level “loud” which is not actually loud, maybe a touch above conversation level? And then 2 DIM settings that I spend a lot of time at when locking in levels. 

DIM 1 is quiet enough to where I would be frustrated if people were talking.

DIM 2 is just barely audible enough to work on, if anything else is going on in the room I could not work.

I find that these consistent levels allow consistent results…specifically with drum/vocal levels. Quieter listing makes it easier to hear balance issues for me.

author: JustinLeu
content:
As others have said Valhalla room is fantastic…I feel like once you master Valhalla room you will fully understand what parameters do what on just about any verb plugin, it gives you just about all the parameters that are possible to edit. 

One thing I have not seen mentioned that I get a LOT of mileage out of:

Try putting a panning plugin BEFORE the stereo reverb (if using as an insert on a track) you can then “place” the instrument “in” the room. You can use a static pan position or if you feel inspired…give slight movement to it. I do this more frequently than an aux send to make stem printing more flexible.

author: tim adamson 🇦🇺
content:
I have a limited understanding but by playing and recording an impulse (see clapping, Ballon pop, sine wave sweep) into a room you measure the response and behaviour of all frequencies in that space(aka the attack, decay etc). 

Then by playing a dry signal through the IR, it recreates a reverb/convulsion of how that sound would behave in the measured space. 

With acoustic instruments just imagine the body of the instrument is like a miniature room that you're measuring. Play a DI track through the IR and the goal is to replicate the acoustic space of the instrument on the dry signal

author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: Ed Sokolowski
content: I make key spikes and run them into sidechain inputs. For a while PT had a smaller limit on delay compensation on sidechains but they increased it a few years ago. I still make dummy outputs for the key tracks which seems to keep the delay compensation updated and happy, never have issues these days. I love being able to use the spikes to put my gates anywhere in the chain, or to key compressors/expanders/gates on reverbs or room mics etc. and my ocd is happier with consistent gating each time, as much as I dig the trigger and sonnox gates, I never 100% trust real time ones.

author: Sei046
content:
I mixed two tracks today that are potentially my best mixes ever, low end is perfect (for me) and the mids are crystal, real 3d, can hear the verbs sitting perfectly, no brittleness in the top end. This was after really struggling the last two weeks. How you ask? I used my 100 euro pair of jbl Bluetooth headphones with horrible mids and super exaggerated lows and highs. For whatever reason the volume balance I was doing on them before a single bit of processing was better than any mix I had done lately. 

So… relook at my room acoustics? The thing is though they sounded great when I threw them up on the system, as I wanted, no big surprises, just sounded way better than on the headphones. 

I found the really exaggerated lows made setting the kick and bass much easier, and the sizzly  top meant I was really sensitive to it and was drawn to address sounds that were a bit harsh. 

It’a a bit like the inverse of working on NS10s. Whatever works I suppose!

author: Rob Domos
content:
@Nomograph Mastering 

There’s so many layers to this conversation. 

One layer is: *are methods of reframing what you’re hearing inherently a crutch for poor monitoring?*

The 400hz high pass that you monitor through part time on every master would imply not. 

As someone with pretty good monitoring (80% of a Gerhard room and MUM 8s), I personally still find these kind of things very useful within a mixing context. 

I think you’re imagining a whackamole scenario of revolving bandpasses throughout the process and repeatedly throwing off the brain’s fr curve, when in reality it’s a once per mix check at the 85% mark that takes about 5 minutes total to see if anything that’s been overlooked jumps out when adjacent information isn’t distracting from it.

The way this helps me hone in on relationships between elements that I’ve been neglecting is pretty significant. I lean heavily “vocal > everything” when I mix, and nearly every time I do this bandpassing reframe I notice something I’d missed in the interplay between the rest of the elements and the whole project is upgraded as a result. 

I think it’s totally fair to warn against the pitfalls of such maneuvers in the same way that it’s fair to warn against abusing energy drinks, but when it’s just once a week before an intense workout, an energy drink is actually a big win with little to no downside.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: Chris Lyon
content:
From my experience, if you focus it on low mids rather than harsh unpleasant frequencies while sidechaining, it can make room for the body of vocals or important instruments to cut through.

A lot of the time, those resonances are the defining characteristics of each sound so side chaining even to harsh high-mid info can allow the character of a focus track to cut while limiting the stacking of those possibly harsh frequencies with other tracks. 

Experiment with the sidechain in mid/side unlinked and you can get more aggressive with sidechaining the lead vocal to the instrumental. In a dense pop mix, it can be a lifesaver.

author: cian riordan
content: I find it useful to just have a grasp on where each section of the song is sitting LUFS-wise. If the first verse is blazing at -6 LUFS, then you're not gonna have much room to go up if you're looking for a lift in the chorus. If the intro of the song is coming in at -22 LUFS, then its probably gonna sound extremely quiet relative to another song's final chorus (or even worse, another song on some streaming playlist).
